Award.AwardTitle: PFI-RP: Data-Driven Services for High Performance and Sustainable Buildings
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader impact/commercial potential of this PFI project will lead to the creation of a truly new breed of building services companies that can provide guaranteed building performance. The results from this proposal will contribute to both building energy efficiency research and practices. Beyond energy conservation, outcomes of the project also have an important societal benefit in advancing the role of a skilled workforce in conjunction with automation. In addition, the proposed effort builds an innovation ecosystem which spans the supply chain for building services and building analytics and automated intelligence suppliers. The proposed research will fulfill an important role in sustainable environments and will enable services with significant economic and human impact. While the building service industry is the focus here, the results obtained have the potential to lead to a better understanding of other human-centered services driven by big data, and will influence the development of novel service platforms applicable to urban operations, such as city-wide transportation control, power grids, and public health, in which system-wise fault discovery and recovery have to be achieved through dynamic spatio-temporal data streams of varying quality and coverage.<br/><br/>The proposed project of Building Doctor's Medicine Cabinet (BDMC) service platform, empowered by novel multi-resolution (temporal and spatial) data analytics, high-dimensional robust modeling, and human-centered interface design, will help building doctors, who are engineers and technicians working in the building service industry, to effectively troubleshoot building problems and to identify systematic and prognostic solutions. BDMC will integrate building datasets from in-situ and control system measurements, knowledge from building doctors, and leverage the patterns and anomalies discovered on this data to (1) diagnose and prognose whole building problems with greatly reduced engineering labor input, false alarms and false dismissals, 2) identify building system hierarchy and develop data-driven energy models; and (3) provide human-centered data visualization and feedback (fault impact analysis and prioritization). The proposed effort will transform the current labor-intensive building service industry into a smart service industry. The main outcomes from this PFI-RP project are algorithms and codes that can be licensed to the industry to be integrated with their existing market products.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This PFI-RP project brings experts from academic institutions and industry experts to form a sustainable partnership to accelerate technology transfer of building management software systems. The principal motivation for this project is to expand our existing partnerships with KGS Building (KGS), a leader in building commissioning and performance management, and our other industrial collaborators and supporters (Johnson Control Inc. (JCI); Kinetic Buildings; Intellimation; and Cimetrics) in order to develop a suite of intelligent and human-centered service systems for building management (e.g., fault detection, diagnosis and prognosis). This customer group includes engineers and technicians working in the building commissioning and energy service industry. It is anticipated that the project outcomes will transform the current labor-intensive building service industry into a smart service industry. The main outcomes from this PFI-RP project are algorithms and codes that can be licensed to the industry to be integrated with their existing market products, such as KGS’ ClockworksTM, which stem from our innovations: (a) big building data analytics; (b) data-driven whole building FDD and prognosis; (c) data-driven fault impact analysis and fault ranking; and (d) human-centered interface. In addition, three undergraduates (two of them are female students), eight graduate students, including one female student, were trained in this project.

Faults (malfunctioning components) in a building are analogous to illnesses in a human body. Unlike building operators, engineers and technicians working in the building service industry (building doctors) are third-party service providers/consultants. The Building Doctor’s Medicine Cabinet (BDMC) provides a platform to help these building doctors specialized in buildings more quickly and accurately perform the most essential aspects of their jobs. The key outcomes from this project are:

1)     A new entropy-based sampling metric based on eigenvalues derived from correlation coefficient matrix, termed, Eigen-Entropy (EE), was developed to support building baseline construction by including qualified samples from historical normal datasets.

2)     Utilizing the EE based baseline model, a Dynamic Bayesian Networks based fault diagnosis framework was developed. It has shown more robust and accurate diagnosis results when compared with traditional Bayesian Networks methods, when being applied to several existing datasets.

3)     A comprehensive Modelica-based fault library using the flexible fault injection framework has been developed. This framework considers a comprehensive list of typical faults in the heating, ventilation, and air-conditioning (HVAC) system in buildings.

4)     A holistic fault impact analysis in a medium-sized office building in a given climate zone was conducted to assess the fault robustness of the high-performance sequences of operation for HVAC systems.

We foresee that the developed BDMC smart services platform will greatly (a) increase the building doctors’ diagnosis accuracy, (b) reduce their labor intensity and engineering hours, therefore (c) reduce the overall service cost and extend building system’s lifespan, and (d) improve the market adoption through higher fault correction rates due to actionable (fault impact and ranking) and prognostic information provided to the building owners. These, in turn, will result in more buildings to be diagnosed and treated in a timely manner and improve the overall energy performance of the building sector. The BDMC services framework could be further developed into a commercial software product in building automation industry. This could be used for retrofitting of buildings to support improved controls and energy savings.

This PFI-RP project is filling an important role in sustainable environments and will enable services with significant economic and human impact. While the building service industry is the focus here, the results obtained have the potential to lead to a better understanding of other human-centered services driven by big data, and will influence the development of novel service platforms applicable to urban operations, such as city-wide transportation control, power grids, and public health, in which system-wise fault discovery and recovery have to be achieved through dynamic spatio-temporal data streams of varying quality and coverage.
